The Witten genus at p=2

Jul 24, 2019

I realized that I’ve been using the term “Witten genus” in too cavalier of a manner: the map is the Witten genus, while the map is the Ando-Hopkins-Rezk orientation. In this previous post (see there for the construction of this -ring which I’ll be relying on), I argued that the map is surjective on homotopy after -completion. We’d like to be able to show the same is true after -completion. Since we know that it is surjective after rationalization, and it is surjective after -completion for by a simple argument (namely, it suffices to construct lifts of and , since is then a polynomial in these variables, as is a -adic unit; but , which maps to , already has and ), we’d find that the Ando-Hopkins-Rezk orientation is indeed surjective on homotopy. In this post, we’ll study the Witten genus , and argue that it (or rather, the composite with ) is surjective on the image of in after -completion. Before proceeding, note that is an equivalence in dimensions (so the generators of and lift to ).

We begin by first calculating the image of in . This isn’t terribly hard to figure out, once you know the homotopy of : we already know that and are in the image of the map , and in the discussion prior to Proposition 8.4 in the linked paper, Bauer states (and later shows) that the classes survive the Adams-Novikov spectral sequence for . All stable homotopy elements are killed in , so we only need to find lifts in of the following multiples of powers of :

We’ll argue as we did for . First recall how survives the ANSS for : we know that in the homotopy groups of spheres; therefore, if the Massey product represents in the ANSS, then must be killed by a differential. Looking at the ANSS chart for , we find that , so . In particular, vanishes in . It follows that if represents a lift of , then the generator in -homology in dimension is sent by to . Since , we find that the map is indeed . Since , we can define in using the same formulae used to define in . We may therefore run the same argument as for to find that there is a class which is mapped to the eponymous class in .

To get all these multiples of powers of , we now run the same trick as in the previous post. Namely, let denote the Thom spectrum of the map ; then, we have maps . It remains to construct maps for , which when composed with the map to , detect the appropriate multiples of powers of . For this, we need to figure out the cell structure of — when , this was vital to being able to write down these maps.

Since we only really care about constructing homotopy elements in (or rather, in ), we can just calculate the bottom few dimensions () of its homotopy via an Adams spectral sequence; the -term of this spectral sequence will be . It is easy via the Cartan formula to write down the structure of as a module (note that suffices because that’s the range through which we care about the homotopy of ), so we can just use Bruner’s Ext program to get the -page. I seem to be unable to produce the Adams chart, although I’m sure that once that’s done it shouldn’t be too hard to figure out that these elements exist… I’ll update this post when I can get these charts.

We can moreover try to lift all the other elements in through this procedure. We’ve already lifted all the -primary elements; so we’ll now lift the -primary elements. We’ll refer to the figure on page 20 of this paper. We’ll illustrate how one can lift all elements up to the -stem of . Recall the map ; since in , we obtain a map , which, when composed with gives . To get and in (of dimensions and , respectively), note (respectively) that and . The same argument as above shows us that the elements listed above do indeed live in . Note that and also exist in and , since exists. For instance, we can get via the relation and the fact that . Looking at the figure in the linked paper, we find that all elements in in dimensions at most in fact lift to .

It gets more complicated as one goes to higher stems, but we can indeed lift all elements of to via these maps . The details will probably appear in my writeup for the UChicago REU.
